basics.name: Michael Falk
basics.label: Computational Literary Scholar
basics.summary: A Romanticist and Digital Humanist, working in Naarm/Melbourne, and living on Darug and Gundungarra country in the Blue Mountains.

work.name: Faculty of Arts, University of Melbourne
work.summary: Co-ordinating the Digital Studies Minor, and conducting original research in Digital Humanities.

work.name: Digital and Social Media, University of Technology Sydney
work.summary: Researcher on ARC-funded project, Wikipedia and the Nation's Story.

work.name: Heurist Network, University of Sydney
work.summary: User support for Humanities Data Management app.

work.name: School of English, University of Kent
work.summary: Teaching and research position in large English department.

publications.name: Romanticism and the Contingent Self: The Challenge of Representation
publications.summary: A digital analysis of the language of selfhood in Romantic literature from Australia, Ireland and elsewhere.

publications.name: Databasing as research: new paradigms for the long tail ...
publications.summary: A discussion of 'databasing as research' as implemented in Heurist; with Ian Johnson.

publications.name: How Australians are Represented in Wikipedia
publications.summary: A thorough examination of the 60,000 biographies of Australians in Wikipedia; with Heather Ford, Kelly Tall and Tamson Pietsch.

publications.name: Three Models of World Literature
publications.summary: How can 'world literature' be modelled computationally? In at least three ways.

publications.name: Artificial Stupidity
publications.summary: We worry about what it means for a machine to be 'intelligent'. But what does it mean for a machine to be 'stupid'?

publications.name: Embodiment in 18th Century Depictions of Human-Machine Co-Creativity
publications.summary: How can humans and machine collaborate to create things? Some ideas from old books. With Anna Kantosalo and Anna Jourdanos.

publications.name: Digital Humanities
publications.summary: An introduction to Digital Humanities from a literary perspective; with Simon Burrows.

publications.name: Stationers, Papetiers and the Supply Networks of a Swiss Publisher: The Sociéte Typographique de Neuchâtel and the Paper Trade 1769–1789
publications.summary: How did the cost of paper shape the Enlightenment? A case study. With Simon Burrows, Rachel Hendery and Katie McDonough.

publications.name: Sad Realities: The Romantic Tragedies of Charles Harpur
publications.summary: The first published analysis of both Harpur's plays: The Bushrangers (1853) and King Saul (c. 1838)

publications.name: The Endless Forms of Things: Harpur's Radicalism Revisited
publications.summary: In what sense was Harpur 'radical'? My intervention in this long-standing scholarly conversation.

publications.name: The Nightjar’s Shriek: Nature’s Variety in the Sonnets of John Clare and Charlotte Smith
publications.summary: A digital comparison of two of the best Romantic sonneteers, who shared a similar passion for precise natural description.

publications.name: Making Connections: Network Analysis, the Bildungsroman, and the World of the Absentee
publications.summary: Analysis of the character-system in Maria Edgeworth's most famous novel, using network analysis.

interests.name: Intellectual History
keywords: History and Philosophy of the Self
History and Philosophy of the Human Sciences

projects.name: wikihistories
projects.summary: wikihistories is an ARC-funded project based at the University of Technology Sydney (DP220100662), and is led by Heather Ford. It aims to uncover how Australia is represented in Wikipedia, and provide a model for further national studies of the encylcopaedia.
